name: pade
description: An R package which when given a vector of Taylor series coefficients of sufficient length as input, the function returns the numerator and denominator coefficients for the Pad√© approximant of appropriate order.
contribution_justification: https://bitbucket.org/aadler/pade/src/master/README.md
floss_license_osi_justification: Disjucntively licensed; both OSI approved
release_notes_justification: https://bitbucket.org/aadler/pade/src/master/inst/NEWS.Rd
build_justification: Can be built by standard R package routines
build_common_tools_justification: Can be built by standard R package routines
test_justification: Uses testthat package to run a suite of tests
warnings_justification: These flags can be passed during the R package building routine
warnings_strict_justification: R CMD Check/Build has its defined warning parameters it passes on compilation
know_common_errors_justification: None of the top-10 errors listed here https://www.owasp.org/images/7/72/OWASP_Top_10-2017_%28en%29.pdf.pdf apply to this software.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Cryptographic hashes are not provided in the CRAN ecosystem.
static_analysis_justification: R CMD check is the language equivalent
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Uses R CMD check mechanism using win-builder and rhub, and the more restrictive --as-cran setting.
dynamic_analysis_justification: No compiled code; all interpreted R code
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: No compiled code; all interpreted R code
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: No compiled code; all interpreted R code
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: BitBucket does not have easily integrated CI for Windows. I test locally and using rhub before I push to CRAN
hardening_justification: The software is an add-in to the R statistical platform and does no I/O in and of itself.It gets checked with memory sanitizer flags on Rhub.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing. // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
installation_common_justification: Uses the R package building system which comes with install and uninstall.
access_continuity_justification:
As a FLOSS project for R, it is easy for anyone to fork/clone the project and assume maintenance even without access to the behind-the-scenes elements of the githup repository. CRAN has been known many times to allow new users to assume maintenance of orphaned projects. THIS github repo may be defunct, but it can be cloned, updated, and the corrections built into the package and pushed to CRAN seamlessly to the end user.

See https://cran.r-project.org/src/contrib/Orphaned/README
bus_factor_justification: As a FLOSS project for R, it is easy for anyone to fork/clone the project and assume maintenance even without access to the behind-the-scenes elements of the githup repository.
documentation_architecture_justification: It is an R package, on CRAN, which means it must conform to https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-exts.html
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Mathematical computation library, so similar to program library in details.
internationalization_justification: Software doesn't generate text intended for end-users and doesn't sort human-readable text
sites_password_security_justification: Project sites do not store passwords for this purpose. It stores SSH key but not password.
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: No vulnerabilities resolved in the last 12 months
coding_standards_enforced_justification: No automatic tool to enforce the specific requirements, although many can be set as Rstudio options or through use of a linter,
build_standard_variables_justification: Built via the R CMD system which honors relevant compiler and linker (environment) variables.
build_preserve_debug_justification: Built via the R CMD system which preserves debugging information.
build_non_recursive_justification: Built via the R CMD system and doesn't use a recursive make.
build_repeatable_justification: Tested using the tinytest suite for R.
installation_standard_variables_justific: Uses the R package building system and follows its standards.
installation_development_quick_justifica: Easily installed by using R and any suite of its tools. Tested on rhub.
dependency_monitoring_justification: As it only imports base R package routines, that is handled by R Core.
interfaces_current_justification: Must use the R build system as it is an R package.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Uses the tinytest package and a suite of tests. https://github.com/aadler/Pade/blob/master/inst/tinytest
implement_secure_design_justification: Installation comes from CRAN or via devtools from GitHub, both of which default to https.
input_validation_justification: Software doesn't accept inputs from untrusted sources. Users will use it individually and pass the needed numbers to it for calculation.
signed_releases_justification: The actual release mechanism is not controlled by me but by CRAN as per https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=Pade

name: GLPI
description: GLPI is a Free Asset and IT Management Software package,ITIL Service Desk, licenses tracking and software auditing.
contribution_justification: http://glpi-developer-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/master/sourcecode.html#workflow
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/COPYING.txt>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/README.md#documentation
documentation_interface_justification: GLPI is only used from its WEB interface, there is no CLI interface (unless we can consider its REST API as an interface usable in CLI).
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The main repository contains all versions of GLPI, whether in BETA, RELEASE-CANDIDATE, STABLE, we manage this in branches "BUGFIXES" (current STABLE version) and "MASTER" (future MAJOR version) : http://glpi-developer-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/master/sourcecode.html#branches
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification:
GLPI follows a semantic versioning scheme, on 3 digits. The first one is the major release, the second the minor and the third the fix release.

Major releases may come with important incompatibilities as well as new features; minor versions may bring new features as well, but stay perfectly compatible inside a major version.

Fixes releases will only fix reported issues without adding anything new.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: GLPI Release notes is carried out according to Keep a Changelog project: <https://keepachangelog.com/en/1.0.0/> which identified "Security" changes.
report_archive_justification: All archive are available on the GitHub project page. Also, GLPI have a forum for old discussions : https://forum.glpi-project.org
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: GLPI doesn't have a page yet that describes the vulnerability reporting process, but have a private mailing-list dedicated for those discussions: : glpi-security@ow2.org
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: GLPI doesn't have a page yet that describes the vulnerability reporting process, but have a private mailing-list dedicated for those discussions: : glpi-security@ow2.org
build_justification: GLPI is developed in PHP, the source code doesn't need to be built.
build_common_tools_justification: GLPI is developed in PHP, the source code doesn't need to be built.
build_floss_tools_justification: GLPI is developed in PHP, the source code doesn't need to be built.
test_justification:
The GLPI test suite is described on this page : https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/tests/README.md
They are mandatory for each contribution, and maintained by core-developers.
test_policy_justification:
Here is the procedure for new Features contribution : https://glpi-developer-documentation.readthedocs.io/en/master/sourcecode.html#features
Every proposal must contains unit tests; for new features as well as bugfixes. For the bugfixes; this is not a strict requirement if this is part of code that is not tested at all yet. See the unit testing section at the bottom of the page.
warnings_justification: GLPI CI process runs Coding Standard tests: <https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/.circleci/config.yml#L63>
crypto_published_justification: GLPI relies on publicly published libraries such as PHP password_hash for users' passwords encryption.
crypto_pfs_justification: No key agreement protocols are implemented by GLPI itself. It relies on HTTPS for some exchanges.
delivery_mitm_justification: Downloads are delivered using HTTPS from the official GLPI GitHub platform.
general_comments:
GLPI stands for **Gestionnaire Libre de Parc Informatique** is a Free Asset and IT Management Software package, that provides ITIL Service Desk features, licenses tracking and software auditing.

GLPI features:
* Inventory of computers, peripherals, network printers and any associated components through an interface, with inventory tools such as: [FusionInventory](http://fusioninventory.org/) or [OCS Inventory](https://www.ocsinventory-ng.org/fr/)
* Data Center Infrastructure Management (DCIM)
* Item lifecycle management
* Licenses management (ITIL compliant)
* Management of warranty and financial information (purchase order, warranty and extension, damping)
* Management of contracts, contacts, documents related to inventory items
* Incidents, requests, problems and changes management
* Knowledge base and Frequently-Asked Questions (FAQ)
* Asset reservation

Moreover, GLPI supports many [plugins](http://plugins.glpi-project.org) that provide additional features.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: ATM, GLPI uses CircleCI <https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/.circleci/config.yml> and TravisCI <https://github.com/glpi-project/glpi/blob/master/.travis.yml> for each commit (on pull-request or not).
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // One or more of the required security hardening headers is missing.

static_analysis_justification: R CMD check is the language equivalent
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: R CMD check  with valgrind is used to check for memory/buffer vulnerabilities as well as using  R with other address sanitizers see <http://dirk.eddelbuettel.com/code/sanitizers.html>

english_justification:

Bug reports and comments accepted at <https://‚Äãgithub.com/‚Äãmerliseclyde/‚ÄãBAS/‚Äãissues>
hardening_justification: Vulnerabilities are not likely in interpreted R code;  C source code uses checks and address sanitizers to identify security vulnerabilities.

build_reproducible_justification: Build to R package via standard R package methods. Tested with Travis continuous integration: <https://travis-ci.org/merliseclyde/BAS> for each commit and on multiple platforms prior to release on CRAN.
governance_justification: <https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md> describes how to make contributions;  developers with significant contributions are listed in <https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS/blob/master/DESCRIPTION.md>
access_continuity_justification: This is an open source package; package development could continue by others by cloning the project.
bus_factor_justification: This is an open source package; package development could continue by others by cloning the project.
documentation_current_justification: Documentation at <https://merliseclyde.github.io/BAS/> is produced using continuous integration via Travis CI with each commit if build is successful in terms of passing R CMD check on the master branch
internationalization_justification:
This is provided by R  for R and C messages as documented at 
<https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-exts.html#Internationalization>
coding_standards_enforced_justification: No FLOSS tool to enforce coding style automatically;  must be run manually at this time.
build_standard_variables_justification: R CMD check --as-cran is language standard
build_preserve_debug_justification: Standards for CRAN apply for building with debugging.
build_repeatable_justification: Not applicable for the package source files; no random seeds are set by the code but are obtained from the scripting language within R
installation_standard_variables_justific: Installs from CRAN  or uses `install.packages` or  package manager within R which supports default/custom installation directories.  Instructions for installing from GitHub are on the package website:   <https://merliseclyde.github.io/BAS>
installation_development_quick_justifica: Installs from CRAN or uses `install.packages` or  package manager within R.  Instructions for installing from GitHub are on the package website:   <https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS>.
external_dependencies_justification: DESCRIPTION file for R: <https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS/blob/master/DESCRIPTION>  lists all package dependencies
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Uses standard components provided by R and contributed packages available through R
interfaces_current_justification: Uses APIs through R for math libraries, etc
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Uses Travis CI for all branches on every commit <https://travis-ci.org/merliseclyde/BAS>   Passing Badge for master branch is shown on < https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS/blob/master/README.md>
implement_secure_design_justification: Installation is secure;  other aspects NA for R packages.
input_validation_justification: Test suite checks inputs: https://github.com/merliseclyde/BAS/tree/master/tests; in general no restrictions on data
signed_releases_justification: Releases on CRAN include the file MD5 which is checked when packages are installed
test_statement_coverage90_justification: codecov is automatically run via Travis CI after each successful build.  Coverage  for R and C code reported at https://codecov.io/github/merliseclyde/BAS?branch=master
test_branch_coverage80_justification: Test suites implemented using testthat; automatically run via R CMD check with Travis CI and codecov
